Award.AwardTitle: CSUMS: Theory, techniques, and research in computational mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Li
0703532

This CSUMS project links faculty from the departments of
mathematics, computer science, and applied science at William and
Mary to create a computational mathematics component in the
undergraduate program. Project personnel modify freshman and
sophomore courses to place greater emphasis on computational
issues, thereby preparing undergraduates for special upper
division courses and eventual participation in undergraduate
research. Students do research projects on theoretical and
practical problems from numerical linear algebra, quantum
computing, optimization, dynamical systems, and mathematical
biology. Typically, students in the program start doing research
in their junior year and the following summer, and continue their
work during their senior year through carefully supervised honors
theses. In addition, academic year activities include special
computational mathematics seminars and visitors, plus an annual
workshop in which students present their discoveries. Important
scientific findings are submitted for publication in professional
journals and presented at scholarly conferences. In addition,
students discuss their results and experiences in local high
schools, in the Virginia Governor's School for Science and
Mathematics, and in regional two-year colleges. Such outreach
presentations should attract a larger and more diverse population
of younger students into further study of computational
mathematics, and give research students in the program additional
practice in communicating mathematics to others. To broaden the
perspective of the students in the program, and to encourage the
interchange of ideas, there are visits to other institutions and
research agencies in the U.S. and abroad. A website is set up
to facilitate communication with other research groups and
computational mathematics programs.

At the base of modern computer and information technology is
an interdisciplinary field called computational mathematics.
This project unites the skills and knowledge of faculty from the
departments of mathematics, computer science, and applied science
to create a new computational component within the undergraduate
curriculum. It prepares students to participate in undergraduate
research projects in the theoretical and practical aspects of
computation, and it builds linkages between the computational
mathematics programs at William and Mary and similar programs
nationally and abroad. Successful experiences in this program
attract students to further study in computational mathematics
and to careers in the field. The diverse research backgrounds of
the program's faculty interact to break down the intellectual
compartmentalization that stands in the way of progress for both
our students and our faculty. The new ideas developed in the
program are disseminated through conference talks and scholarly
publication by our students and their faculty mentors. Through
outreach to high school and community college programs, they
attract a larger and more diverse group of pre-college students
into computational mathematics programs here and elsewhere. The
project is supported by the MPS Division of Mathematical
Sciences, the MPS Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, and the
EHR Division of Undergraduate Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The William & Mary CSUMS program introduced new courses including Topics in Computational Mathematics, Introduction to Quantum Computing, and a Freshmen Seminar on topics in computational mathematics in the curriculum to heighten the general awareness of the computational issues in different areas. We also strengthened the computational aspects in the existing courses so that students could be exposed to the connections of computational issues in both traditional and modern topics. In additionto making changes in the curriculum, a CSUMS seminar series was established, and students were encouraged to attend. This further promoted the understanding of computational issues, and promoted a culture in which students take an active part in research-related activities.

An undergraduate research program was held each summer from 2008 to 2012. Over 70 students received full or partial support to participate in CSUMS research projects. They were exposed to interdisciplinary  research topics in mathematical biology, quantum information science, optimization, compressed sensing, statistics, network and graph theory, etc., that require an interplay between computation and mathematics or statistics. Research groups, with CSUMS advisers, were formed. In the group activities, students gain experiences in research, and also learned how to communicate mathematical results and ideas via listening and giving talks based on their work, and preparing their written reports. Many research students (71%) continued their research and finished honors theses, and over 52% of the students entered graduate schools in mathematics and science. Many  findings in the research projects were submitted to refereed journal leading to 28 publications. This reflects the high standard of the research projects, and the research training that was provided to students. Furthermore, 34% of the student participants were women, and 4% were members of an underrepresented minority.

The program stimulated a series of CSUMS conferences as well as other undergraduate conferences, where students and faculty advisers could share their experiences. Moreover, students gained experience in communicating mathematical ideas with other people. Research students also gave presentations and participated in poster sessions in  a number of conferences and won a number of awards. Furthermore, some students gained international experience by visiting research groups or attending conferences in other countries such as Germany, Serbia, Czech Republic, China, Hong Kong, etc. This significantly broadened the perspective of students.

Intellectual merits. In our CSUMS program, students were exposed to contemporary mathematics, statistics, and computation, addressed with modern research tools and methods. Using these tools and methods, students formed research groups with advisers. Research progress was made in various problems leading to better understanding of the subjects, and solutions of some open problems. The findings were published in research journals and disseminated at conferences. These will definitely help advance various research topics.

Broader impact. In addition to the scientific findings, the most important contributions of the CSUMS project is on the development of human resources in mathematics and science. In the project, students received rigorous research training. They acquired the skills of doing research and communicating mathematics, and developed interest in scientific research.
